data.title: Musicians Born on July 7
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays in music for the 7th of July. See which composers, musicians, pop stars and rockers were born on July 7.
data.text:
Johann Tobias Krebs, German organist and composer, born in Heichelheim, Duchy of Saxe-Weimar (d. 1762)

Arvid Niclas von Höpken, Swedish nobleman, soldier, and composer (Il Re Pastore), born in Stockholm, Sweden (d. 1778)

Ludwig Wenzel Lachnith, Bohemian horn player and composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia, Habsburg Empire (d. 1820)

Antonio Francesco Gaetano S Pacini, Italian-French composer and music publisher, born in Naples, Kingdom of Naples (d. 1866)

Charles Tindley, American gospel music composer ("I'll Overcome Someday"), and Methodist minister, born in Berlin, Maryland (d. 1933)

Gustav Mahler

Austrian composer (Symphony No. 2 - "Resurrection"), and conductor (New York Philharmonic, 1909-11), born in Kalischat, Kingdom of Bohemia, Habsburg Empire

Juan Lamote de Grignon, Catalan pianist, composer (La nit de Nadal (Christmas Night); Hespèria), and orchestra leader (Cobla Barcelona; València Municipal Orchestra), born in Barcelona, Spain (d. 1949)

Jacob Weinberg, Russian-born Jewish composer, born in Odessa, Ukraine (d. 1956)

Zdzislaw Jachimecki, Polish composer and music historian, born in Lwów, Ukraine (d. 1953)

Toivo Kuula, Finnish composer, born in Vehkakoski, Grand Duchy of Finland, Russian Empire (d. 1918)

Ernest Farrar, English composer whose career was cut short by WWI, born in London (d. 1918)

James McCartney, British cotton salesman, amateur musician, and father of Beatle Paul McCartney, born in Everton, Liverpool, England (d. 1976)

Marcel Rubin, Austrian composer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1995)

Anton Karas, Austrian zither player and composer (The Third Man), born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1985)

Gian-Carlo Menotti, Italian pianist, librettist, and composer (Amahl & Night Visitors), and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, born in Cadegliano, Italy (d. 2007)

1911 Joan Perry [Elizabeth Rosiland Miller], American film actress, model, and singer (Hands of a Stranger), born in Pensacola, Florida (d. 1996)

Cor de Groot, Dutch pianist, conductor and composer (Old-Dutch Suite), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1993)

1914 Serafim Tulikov, Russian composer (March of the Soviet Youth), born in Kaluga, Russia (d. 2004)

Lloyd "Tiny" Grimes, American jazz and R&B guitarist (Art Tatum), born in Newport News, Virginia (d. 1989)

1916 Robert Stevens Baker, American organist, composer, and educator (Union Theological Seminary, 1961-72; Institute of Sacred Music at Yale, 1973-75), born in Pontiac, Illinois (d. 2005)

(Woodrow Wilson) "Red" Sovine, American country music singer ("Phantom 309"; "Teddy Bear"), born in Charleston, West Virginia (d. 1980)

1917 Elton Britt [Baker], American country singer-songwriter ("There's a Star-Spangled Banner Waving Somewhere"; Saturday Night Jamboree), born in Zack, Arkansas (d. 1972)

Stanislaw Wislocki, Polish conductor, born in Rzeszów, Poland (d. 1998)

Artie Malvin, American vocalist (Glenn Miller; Jimmy Dorsey), arranger and music director (Julie LaRosa; Pat Boone; Carol Burnett), born in New York City (d. 2006)

Roberto Caamaño, Argentine composer, born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1993)

Dieter Nowka, German composer, conductor and musicologist, born in Madlow, Germany (d. 1998)

1924 Mary Ford [Iris Colleen Summers], American vocalist (with Les Paul - "How High The Moon"), born in El Monte, California (d. 1977)

(Carl) "Doc" Severinsen, American trumpeter and bandleader (The Tonight Show, 1962-92), born in Arlington, Oregon

1927 Charlie Louvin [Loudermilk], American country singer-songwriter, and guitarist (Louvin Brothers - "The Only Way Out (Is to Walk Over Me)"), born in Section, Alabama (d. 2011)

Hank Mobley, American hard bop and soul jazz saxophonist, born in Eastman, Georgia (d. 1986)

[Josef] Joe Zawinul, Austrian-American jazz keyboardist, composer and bandleader (Weather Report - "Birdland"), born in Vienna, Austria (d. 2007)

Vinko Globokar, French-Slovenian trombone player and avant-garde composer (Eppure si muove), born in Anderny, France

Friedhelm Döhl, German composer, born in Göttingen, Germany (d. 2018)

1936 Nikos Xilouris, Greek folk singer-songwriter, born in Anogeia, Crete, Greece (d. 1980)

1936 Stuart Dempster, American trombonist, didgeridoo player, and composer, born in Berkeley, California

Ringo Starr

British drummer, vocalist (The Beatles - "Yellow Submarine"), songwriter ("Early 1970"; "Photograph"), actor (Caveman), "peace & love" activist, and knight, born in Dingle, Liverpool, England [1]

Jim Rodford, English rock bassist (Argent, 1969-76; The Kinks, 1978-96; Zombies, 2004-18), born in St Albans, Hertfordshire, England (d. 2018)

Chris Stamp, British music producer, psychodrama therapist and manager (The Who, Jimi Hendrix), born in London, England (d. 2012)

(Salvatore) "Toto" Cutugno, Italian pop singer-songwriter ("L'Italiano", Eurovision, 1990; "Insieme: 1992"), born in Tendola, Tuscany, Italy (d. 2023)

Warren Entner, American rock vocalist, guitarist, and organist (The Grass Roots - "Midnight Confessions", "Let's Live for Today"), born in Boston, Massachusetts

Matti Salminen, Finnish bass player (King Philipp - "Don Carlos"), born in Turku, Finland

Rob Townsend, British drummer (Family; The Blues Band), born near Frog Island, Leicester, England

Larry "Rhino" Reinhardt, American rock guitarist (Iron Butterfly), born in Florida (d. 2012)

Berry Sakharof, Turkish-born Israeli rock guitarist and singer-songwriter (Minimal Compact), born in İzmir, Turkey

Michael Kieran Harvey, Australian classical and contemporary music pianist and composer (GRETA - Concerto in No Need of an Orchestra), born in Sydney, Australia

Clive Jackson, British rock singer (Doctor and the Medics - "Laughing at Pieces"), born in Liverpool, England

1962 Mark White, American rock bass player (Spin Doctors - "Two Princes"; "Jimmy Olsen's Blues"), born in The Bronx, New York City

Perry Richardson, American bassist (Firehouse - "Love of a Lifetime"), born in Conway, South Carolina

1963 Vonda Shepard, American pop singer-songwriter, and actress (Ally McBeal), born in New York City

Theo Travis, British progressive rock and ambient music saxophonist, flautist, and composer (Soft Machine/Legacy, 2006-present; Gong, 1999-2010), born in Birmingham, England

Gundula Krause, German folk violinist, born in Göttingen, Germany

Jackie Neal, American blues singer-songwriter ("Right Thang, Wrong Man"), born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana (d. 2005)

Nathalie Simard, French Canadian singer, born in Île d'Orléans, Quebec

Robia LaMorte, American actress and dancer, born in Queens, New York City

Misia [Misaki Itō], Japanese singer (Mother Father Brother Sister), born in Omura, Japan

Dan Whitesides, American drummer (The Used, 2006-), born in Salt Lake City, Utah

1980 Kaisa Jouhki, Finnish vocalist (Battlelore), born in Sumatra, Indonesia

Synyster Gates, American guitarist (Avenged Sevenfold), born in Long Beach, California

Cassidy [Barry Adrian Reese], American rapper, born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

1982 Mike Glita, American bassist (Senses Fail), born in Livingston, New Jersey

D. Woods [Wanita Denise Woodgett], American pop and hip-hop singer (Danity Kane), born in Anaheim, California

Marie-Mai [Bouchard], French Canadian pop singer ("Jamais trop tard"), born in Varennes, Quebec

Kaci Brown, American pop and country music singer ("Instigator"; Brown & Gray), born in Sulphur Springs, Texas
